body: I also have a similar question. How to let other users work together for the data annotation within a same project?
Right now, different users cannot work in the same project. In such a case, you can share your account with others.

doccano supports multi-user annotation. Right now, they can annotate same parts of dataset but they cannot annotate different parts of dataset.

If you want to do it, please split your dataset, create multi projects and assign users to each project.

Is this feature necessary?
If the users think so, please vote up.

According to the number, I will consider the implementation.
@Hironsan This feature would be super useful for one of my upcoming projects. If you wish, I could help with implementation.
@c-w Thanks for your proposal. I'm sure your help is really helpful.
@Hironsan Could you share any thoughts you have on design or architecture for the feature as a starting point?

Ideally it would be nice to have N users in the system, configure it such that each sample needed atleast K judgements and then allocate it to the users on a first-come first basis till that K limit is hit. 

We've had to do this in our current (much less polished) system because if users stopped tagging then pre-allocated samples would sit idle.

issue.title: How to add new users  for current project? Thank you advance.

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
If there any method to let other users join my project?
I don't want to divide data into many parts.
Thank you for your help.

body:
@bsatts The behavior you described is probably the best, but I feel it may require a lot of changes to make real time allocation works.

How about a lesser version like this:
- documents are pre allocated and users only see theirs documents
- admin have an interface to manage and reallocate documents per user with function like transfer from one user to another, redistribute everything

What do you think?
Yeah that would be pretty reasonable.

A simple solution is dynamic filtering. It is not perfect but it can filter documents by the number of annotated users. We can specify it by `k`. The endpoint is like <http://127.0.0.1:8000/v1/projects/1/docs?k=3>.

```python
from django_filters.rest_framework import FilterSet, NumberFilter
from django.db.models import Count
from .models import Document


class DocumentFilter(FilterSet):

    def get_k(self, queryset, name, value):
        docs = queryset.annotate(num=Count('seq_annotations__user', distinct=True))
        return docs.filter(num__lt=value)

    k = NumberFilter(method='get_k')

    class Meta:
        model = Document
```

Once we set `k` in a project, we can use it when fetching documents in an annotation page. Annotators don't have to care about k. All things are performed in the background.

From a viewpoint of implementation, I think it does not require a lot of changes: add DocumentFilter's condition, add a column for `k` to Project model and change frontend(`search` method in annotation page).

issue.title: Login via command line

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
------------------------

I'm running Docanno via Docker in my local and everything is ok up and running

Whenever we login, we see the Django login screen before we can access the projects. We would like to be able to skip this step and login via the command line instead. This is so that we can have many anonymous users login as a user with access to all projects but do not gain the information or access all of the other projects besides the ones we assign them. Is there a possibility to change the script such that login is an automatic process?

issue.title: Enhancement/Approve labels

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/249, it is a very useful feature to enable a type of users to review and approve labels that other users annotated. The review feature for example enables workflows like the ones discussed in https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/65 where many users can annotate the dataset and then some trusted users can verify the labels before we use them for downstream workflows such as model building.

As such, this pull request implements a simple label review mechanism: admin users now see a button on the annotation page that enables them to approve or reject labels. The approval is shown in the exported datasets so that downstream applications can exclude non-approved labels.

![Animation showing label approving workflow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1086421/60116855-e959eb80-9746-11e9-9c4c-8e3418264a34.gif)

In the future, this feature can be expanded to for example include multiple reviewers per document or to provide a customized "label reviewer" role whose document sort order by default shows labeled but not-reviewed documents first in the annotation view.

body:
> A simple solution is dynamic filtering. It is not perfect but it can filter documents by the number of annotated users. We can specify it by `k`. The endpoint is like http://127.0.0.1:8000/v1/projects/1/docs?k=3.
> 
> ```python
> from django_filters.rest_framework import FilterSet, NumberFilter
> from django.db.models import Count
> from .models import Document
> 
> 
> class DocumentFilter(FilterSet):
> 
>     def get_k(self, queryset, name, value):
>         docs = queryset.annotate(num=Count('seq_annotations__user', distinct=True))
>         return docs.filter(num__lt=value)
> 
>     k = NumberFilter(method='get_k')
> 
>     class Meta:
>         model = Document
> ```
> 
> Once we set `k` in a project, we can use it when fetching documents in an annotation page. Annotators don't have to care about k. All things are performed in the background.
> 
> From a viewpoint of implementation, I think it does not require a lot of changes: add DocumentFilter's condition, add a column for `k` to Project model and change frontend(`search` method in annotation page).

Some documents will get annotated for more than k times, since there is no synchronization in the UI. Users click next, the data in this page remains the same as the first time this pages fetch from the server. So, the next document might be annotated by other users too.
